name: Avoid SQL injection
associatedValueName: Call stack from user input source down to the target SQL execution method
description: This quality rule identifies SQL injection vulnerabilities by analyzing data flow paths from user input sources to SQL query execution points. The rule uses CAST's data-flow engine to detect when user-controllable data is directly concatenated or interpolated into SQL statements without proper validation, sanitization, or parameterization. It searches for patterns where untrusted input flows into SQL queries through string concatenation, string formatting, or dynamic query construction methods.
output:
List all methods that make resource calls forged by user input

It provides the following information:
 - Method full name
 - Call stack from user input source down to the target SQL execution method.
rationale:
The software constructs all or part of an SQL command via user-controllable inputs. These inputs are not neutralized or are incorrectly neutralized. As a consequence, the SQL command may be completely altered.
Critical consequences include: data breach (Attackers can access sensitive information), authentication bypass, data integrity compromise, system compromise, etc.
reference:

https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/89.html

https://cheatsheetseries.owasp.org/cheatsheets/SQL_Injection_Prevention_Cheat_Sheet.html

CISQ rule: ASCSM-CWE-89.
remediation:
To prevent SQL injection vulnerabilities, implement these security measures:
-Use parameterized queries/prepared statements
-Use stored procedures with parameters
-Use vetted ORM libraries like Spring Data JPA or Entity Framework Core.
alternativeName: Ensure you don't send unsanitized queries to SQL databases
